content:
As a data analyst at Volt Data Lab, I participated in some projects that involved data collection, analysis and visualization, from many different sources.
  Science Pulse: online tool to connect journalists to scientific conversation in social media, by finding content from a list of trustworthy sources of experts/researchers who engage on social media (mainly on Twitter). This project involved working with R on remote servers and Shiny.
  R Packages: two packages to extract data from APIs developed by Volt Data Lab: pollingBR, which gets data about electoral polls compiled by news website Poder360; and crossfire, that gets data about gun shootings in Rio de Janeiro and Recife’s metropolitan areas, collected by the Fogo Cruzado initiative.
  Data and statics on podcasts in Brazil, 2019 (in Portuguese): report produced by Sérgio Spagnuolo and I, in which we collected and analysed data on Brazilian and International podcasts hosted on Pocket Casts. Data was collected in July and August, 2019 and the code can be found on GitHub.
  Terra de Resistentes: collaborative project which investigates threats to environmental leaders and their communities in seven countries on Latin America. I contributed with data analysis and visualization on threats to indigenous communities in Rondônia. This story involved data analysis from indigenous lands, deforestation, illegal roads, hidrography, mining and rural lands.
summary: Contributions in Volt Data Lab's projects (2019 and 2020)
title: Projects - Volt Data Lab

content:
How did the city of São Paulo responded to the first weeks' challenges of the new coronavirus pandemic?. In this blog post, I described the first measures taken by mayor Bruno Covas (PSDB) and his relationship with governor João Doria (PSDB). I also discussed the main health, social care and urban transportation policies during this period. To conclude, I pointed out some of the challenges the city was poised to face: how to maintain isolation policies, reach vulnerable populations, increase testing and hospital capacities and planning the economy reopening.
This post was published on April 7th, 2020, in Portuguese (original title “São Paulo: alinhamento subnacional e os desafios do combate à Covid-19 na maior cidade do país”) in the blog series “Municipal governments facing the coronavirus” from the Study Group on Local Politics (NEPOL), Federal University of Juiz de Fora.
summary: Blog post in the series "Municipal governments facing the coronavirus" (NEPOL-UFJF, April 2020)
title: São Paulo: subnational alignment and challenges from Covid-19 in the country`s largest city

content:
How did Jair Bolsonaro’s evaluation was compared to other world leaders on the first weeks of the new coronavirus pandemic? By comparing surveys about the Brazilian president approval rating with others from seven world leaders, I found that, unlike the others, Bolsonaro was the only who did not get a bump on his approval ratings in the period. I analyzed the result from the perspective of the rally-round-the-flag-effect which can explain political leaders' sudden increase in approval during hard times.
Analysis published in portuguese on Núcleo Jornalismo., on April 1st, 2020. Original title: Na contramão de outros líderes, avaliação de Bolsonaro fica estagnada durante pandemia. Data and code are available on the hyperlinks.
title: Unlike other world leaders, Bolsonaro`s evaluation does not change during the pandemic

content:
In March 2018, after a news website published a short note Marielle Franco’s number of votes at the Maré neighborhood, I published an analysis on Medium called Territorial Representation and Marielle Franco (in portuguese), which showed how her votes were distributed across the city of Rio de Janeiro que investigava a distribuição dos votos dela na cidade do Rio de Janeiro.
In the text I discuss some precautions and data issues for spatial analysis of Brazilian election, and I also present some ideas on “territorial representation”.
Code used in the analysis is available in a repo on my GitHub profile.
title: Territorial Representation and Marielle Franco

content:
R Packages pollingBR pollingBR is a R package created to facilitate the extraction of date from the dataset of Brazilian electoral polls from the news website Poder360. The package extracts information from its’ open data API, developed by Volt Data Lab. The package was developed with contributions from Sérgio Spagnuolo, Denisson Silva and Fernando Meireles.
To download it and for further instructions, please check the pollingBR repository on GitHub.
crossfire crossfire is a R package to extract data from Fogo Cruzado’s open data API, also developed by Volt Data Lab. Fogo Cruzado (Crossfire) is “a collaborative and digital platform to register gun shootings and gun violence on the metropolitan areas of Rio de Janeiro and Recife”. The package was developed with contributions from Sérgio Spagnuolo and Denisson Silva.
To download it and for further instructions, please check the crossfire repository on GitHub.
newsatlasbr newsatlasbr is a R Package to extract data from News Atlas open data API. News Atlas is a project which maps Brazilian news outlets. I developed this package with contributions from Sérgio Spagnuolo and Renata Hirota.
To download it and for further instructions, please check the newsatlasbr repository on GitHub.
summary: R Packages pollingBR pollingBR is a R package created to facilitate the extraction of date from the dataset of Brazilian electoral polls from the news website Poder360. The package extracts information from its’ open data API, developed by Volt Data Lab.
title: Software
